name: White-winged Duck
description: Though it appears mostly dark at first glance except for a white-spotted head, its name isn’t a mistake: it has a white patch on its wings, visible only in flight.
spread_note: Patchily from India to Southeast Asia
proportions: Length 66–68 cm; wingspan 116–153 cm; weight 1.9–3.8 kg
attractions: Like other muscovy ducks, it nests in tree hollows and rests in trees. It lives solitary or in pairs and is very shy. It often forages in shallows at night.
projects_note: The white-winged duck relies on mature trees. It once inhabited a vast range from northeastern India to Sumatra and Java. Due to intensive deforestation, wetland drainage, dam construction, and other environmental impacts, their numbers declined, with the current population estimated at just 400–450 birds. Its range is now fragmented into isolated subpopulations with little chance of interaction. It’s listed as endangered on the IUCN Red List.
breeding: We’ve kept them since 1997, and they’ve been breeding since 2007.
